titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VI. This Morning my wife, with my Son George, Mary Hellen, and the domestics Elizabethand Joseph Abbot the Coachman, left my fathers House at Quincy to return to our own residence at the City of Washington— As she travels with our own carriage, and of course slowly, we agreed that they should depart this day, and proceed by such Stages as to reach New-London on Thursday; and I am to overtake them there, by going in the Stage of that day from Boston— We propose to proceed thence together in the Steam-Boats to New-York, sending the carriage and horses round by land— From New-York, I am to proceed immediately, having written to Mr Brent that my purpose is to reach Washington, the 10th. of this Month. My Son Charles went with W. S. Shaw in the Stage to Boston, and thence to Cambridge where the term at the University effectually commences this day. After bespeaking a seat in the Stage to Boston for to-morrow Morning, I went with John to Boston and thence to Cambridge— I stopped at President Kirkland’s, and spoke to him on the subject of my Sons— I told him I had been much mortified and surprized at discovering their low standing as Scholars in their classes. I asked him if there had been any thing exceptionable in their moral conduct? He said, absolutely nothing— He had never heard so much as a word against either of them. This, I told him was a great consolation to me— But it was best to deal perfectly in candour with him— My eldest Son, left the University, with a deep impression, that justice had not been done him other in the standing attributed to him, or in the part assigned to him at Commencement: and I shared with him in the opinion— He stood rated in his Class number 30—and his part was one of the lowest, assigned for the day. Now I would advert to the following facts— At the Boylston prize-declamations of the last year, George took the first prize— His performance on Commencement day, was distinguished as one of the best, by the public approbation, and even noticed as such in the public Journals— But one of his Classmates who on the recitation lists stood within the first twenty had applied to George to write his part for him; George wrote it; and it was actually delivered— When George presented to Mr Channing before Commencement his own part, it was returned to him without remark either of approbation or censure— But when the part which had been written by George for his friend, was brought up to the professor, he had in returning it, expressed himself of it, in terms of high commendation— Dr. Kirkland said that one subject might present more opportunity for elegant composition than another— I was aware of that, and added that neither of these incidents was decisive in itself— It was the combination of them which wrought upon me— He said he had thought George was satisfied with the standing and the part assigned to him. I assured him it was far otherwise; but that as he had finished his career at the University, I should not have complained, but that I have yet two Sons there, for whom it is my duty to obtain Justice— I had been informed that John had at the close of his freshman year received a private admonition for neglect of his studies. This was cause of deep regret to me, because I must presume he had deserved it— But he and his brother had both solemnly assured me that he had since that time been a close and regular student. Yet I found his standing had been raised no more than from 47 to 45. And his mark upon recitation to Mr Channing was among the very lowest, rating him at 5—while in fact he had declared to me, that he had a peculiar fondness for that study, and would appeal to his whole class, whether he had not been constant in his attendance and correct in his recitations— If Mr Channing’s mark had been, as I believed it ought to have been at least 9. that would have raised John’s standing upon the general scale above 40. And now upon my son Charles’s examination, it was Mr Channing again who fixed upon him the stigma, of a Condition— It had been my fortune two years ago, quite unwillingly, but from the conviction of duty to be made the vehicle of communications to the Board of Overseers, objecting against his appointment of professor of Rhetoric and Oratory— I supposed this was known to Mr Channing. I was unwilling to believe that
he indulged his resentments against me by injustice to my children— Yet this peculiar severity applied to them all, could not be without a cause— Dr Kirkland said he hoped that no such prejudice would operate upon the mind of Mr Channing— That as to John, it was the usage of the Government not to give the Parents of the young men notice of the first admonition; but they did give notice when there was occasion for the second. He shewed me that John’s mark in Greek, the recitation of which was to Dr Popkin, rated him still lower than he was rated in rhetoric by Mr Channing. He said if he had lately studied more, without much rising, it might be owing to his frequent absences upon leave; which though not subjecting him to punishment, could not but have an effect upon his recitations. He said it was John’s principle, and that of many others, to avail themselves of every indulgence and relaxation which could escape from actual punishment. With this principle they may pass through college, but cannot make distinguished Scholars. I finally said that having disburthened my mind, I should wait for the result of another year; I hoped I should have no further cause even for suspicion of injustice towards my sons. Should it be otherwise it would be very painful to me to remove them; but my duty to them would require it. I could not witness their mortifications, and discouragements, from partialities operating against them upon their teachers; and would place them elsewhere— I then went to John’s chamber, and took leave of him and Charles—told them they were to pass their next Winter vacation, at my fathers at Quincy— That I should expect they would both pursue their studies steadily and assiduously— That the winter after next if I should then be still residing at Washington, my permission to them to come there would depend upon their standing as Scholars, but it must be much higher than that now held by John— I enjoined upon them a persevering attendance upon all the exercise, and forbad them to take out their names for absence even to go to Quincy during the term— I saw they were much affected, John especially by the loss of the visit to Washington next Winter, but my determination was taken, and they did not venture to remonstrate— I went immediately to Read’s for my Chaise; came to Roxbury where I dined with R. G. Amory, and in the Evening returned to my father’s house at Quincy— There was a party of fourteen or fifteen Gentlemen, at Amory’s, among whom were judge Davis, W. Prescott, G. Blake, and E. S. L. Livermore; and Lieutt Stockton, whom I agreed to meet to-morrow Morning at ten O’Clock, in Boston— I rode in a heavy rain almost the whole of this day.

2. V:30. This was a training day at Quincy, and all the neighbourhood was under arms or upon the field— The Stage in which I had engaged a seat did not go to Boston, but they sent me in a Chaise in its stead— I passed through regiments of militia from my fathers house to Neponset Bridge, and crowds of Spectators, flocking by their sides— I reached Mrs Jenks’s just in time to meet Lieutt. Stockton at ten. He gave me the written statement of particulars respecting the capture by him of four Schooners on the Coast of Africa, under French Colours— He also shewed me a very polite note from William Sullivan, with a summons to appear on the 15th of next October before the Circuit Court at Boston, to answer for the capture of the Schooner Eliza; damages bid at twenty thousand dollars. Stockton said that as it was deferred till October next he should have time enough for preparation; but I told him it was merely a mistake of the clerk in making out the summons, and that the time of appearance was the 15th. of the present month; but as he was not held to bail, he would not be personally detained, but might go to Sea, and appear in Court by his Attorney. As to the delivery of the captured vessel now here to the French Consul, he said he should not object to it, if he was considered as relieved from all responsibility for the capture. He is now under sailing orders and expects to go in a few days. He told me he proposed to go to Quincy and see my father, at his invitation to-morrow— After this
interview, I called upon General Dearborn the elder, according to appointment at 11. O’Clock; and found with him his son in Law, General Wingate— This Gentleman is an inhabitant of the State of Maine and was an unsuccessful candidate, at the recent election of Governor there. In this contest the late Governor King, and Mr Holmes took part against him, and in favour of judge Albion K. Parris, who was elected. This will occasion a vacancy of the office of U.S. District judge, and General Dearborn told me he was apprehensive there would be efforts made, to precipitate the appointment of Ashur Ware, now Secretary of State in Maine, as District Judge. He said he had written to the President, suggesting to him the wish that the appointment might be deferred until the meeting of the Legislature in Maine; when the wishes of a majority of the members might be consulted in the appointment of the judge— Mr Ware was not a proper person for that office— He was a young man who had not been more than five years a resident in the State, having had very little experience or reputation as a lawyer— There were two other persons either of them better qualified for and suited to the place— Mr Whitman, a federalist, but a man of talents, a sound lawyer, of irreproachable character—and Mrnow Speaker of the House of Representative, an eminent lawyer, and whose appointment would give general satisfaction— But the appointment of Ware, would be, as the election of Parris had been a part of the system for securing the election of Mr Crawford, as successor to the present President— To this end the vote of the State of Maine, was considered as of very great importance— About three years ago, he understood Mr Rufus King wrote a letter to his brother William, expressing the opinion that Mr Crawford would carry the next election—for President, by the superiority of his talent for electioneering management— William King thereupon immediately determined to be of the strongest side; went to Richmond in Virginia, where he made his arrangements— Then returned home, stopping at Washington City, where he was promised in the event of success, the Office of Secretary of War, the great object of his ambition.— Mr Holmes has since been secured by the promise of a foreign Mission, and General Chandler by his connections with the others; and now King since his return from Washington last June, has been canvassing the State openly and with such profusion of promises that it reminded him of a recruiting Officer, who always enlisted men by promising every individual that he should be made a Sergeant. He had no doubt that if they should succeed not one officer of the United States within the State, removable by the Executive would be suffered to keep his place— Every one would be turned out— But there were not enough of them—there were ten promises or more for every office, and the disappointments would be so much more numerous than the fulfilments, that ultimately there would be more enemies made than partizans— But his object in asking to see me before my return to the seat of Government was to caution me, with regard to my relations with these men— I might rely upon it, they would keep a continual watch upon me, and would snatch at any thing I might do or say that they could possibly turn to my disadvantage— I told the General that I was obliged to him for his kindness. That Mr W. King had long been canvassing for Mr Crawford in the State of Maine, was well known to me, and that he had freely assigned that Gentleman’s superior talent for political management, as the presage of his success, I had also heard— Of Mr Holmes my information had not been so positive, but from his late coalition with King, and the part he had taken in the late State Election of Maine, I had inferred what his course would be with regard to the next Presidential Election. I could certainly not answer that I should always be so guarded in my conduct, as to give them no power to injure me, if they should be so disposed— I ought not to expect it from them; but I was aware that my security would only be in proportion to my discretion. As to the appointment of District judge I had no doubt the President would use due deliberation before making it. The General asked if there was any person at Washington, to whom he could write freely, should any thing occur, of which he might wish to give me information— I said perhaps some one of the Representatives from the State, but I was not acquainted with the new Members. Wingate mentioned
Mr Herrick as a well disposed man; I said Mr M. L. Hill, so far as inferences could be drawn from his Conversation was a trusty person— They said he would be too much under the influence of the others— General Dearborn, asked me, whether Mr Bailey, might be considered as a confidential man— I told him, entirely so— This conversation was of about two hours duration, and I have only here minuted its material points. Dearborn, and Wingate are irritated, not only at the failure of the latter, but at the coarseness and intemperance with which King and Holmes have carried on the electioneering campaign against him— Whether King has been so prodigal of his promises, and whether he or Holmes have received such promises as Dearborn affirms, I pause, absolutely to believe; but that King, from selfish motives, and from his confidence in Crawford’s superior talent, at political intrigue, has made himself his partizan, and drawn Holmes into the same course, I have no doubt. That in producing this result, Rufus King gave the first impulse to his brother is new to me, but not surprizing— Rufus King has himself been, and wishes again to be a candidate for the presidency; and although personally a friend of mine of long standing, he is not unwilling to guard against the possibility of my standing in his way. This is not the first occasion upon which I have felt the effects of this disposition— Yet I do not agree to the characteristic which Clay gave me of him last Spring—that he was “a hollow-hearted, insincere man.” He is upright in principle; and occasionally frail in practice— Leaving General Dearborn’s, I met Mr Edward Cruft in the Street, and called with him at the Fire and Marine Insurance Office— Thence I went to the Marlborough Hotel, and engaged a seat in the Stage for New-London, for Thursday Morning. As it starts from the House at 3. in the morning, I bespoke a lodging for to-morrow night— Dined with Mr Hall the Sheriff— Besides his family the only other guest present was Nathl. Amory.De Grand called there after dinner to remind me that I had promised to meet him and a Committee of Memorialists to the President; it had entirely escaped my Memory. I promised to meet them to-morrow Evening at seven. I sent to Spurr’s for a horse and Chaise, and calling at Dr Welsh’s persuaded Harriet to go with me out to Quincy, to pass the remainder of the week at my father’s. We met multitudes of Carriages, returning from the training, all the way from the Neck to Neponset Bridge; and thence to my father’s house were annoyed by the straggling militia men, and fragments of companies returning home after the review. Mr. Marston and Mr Quincy passed the Evening with us at my father’s. Marston stated to me in a very pathetic manner his distressed circumstances which I wish, it were in my power to relieve.

3. V:30. I wrote to Mr D. Brent and made up the last packages to be forwarded to the Department of State, which occupied great part of the morning. Attempted a Settlement of accounts with my brother, but found I had omitted to bring with me from Washington some of his former accounts; so that I was obliged to leave the Settlement incomplete— He will forward the account to me at the end of the year. Packed up a Chest of Books to be sent on to Washington— Mr George Blake, and Lieutenant Stockton came and dined at my father’s, but I was so much engaged that I saw them only while at dinner— At 5 this afternoon, I took leave of the family and of my father, who taking me by the hand said to me, “be thou faithful, as thou hast been, unto the death, and thou shalt surely have a crown of glory, here and hereafter.” I was too much affected with the sentiment of his heart that these might be the last words he should ever speak to me; to reply more than that I hoped to see him again next Summer, and I hurried to my Chaise at the gate— I drove immediately into Boston, musing upon the prospects of the future; upon the duties arduous and complicated, still before me, upon the goodness and power of the being who has hitherto protected and guided
me, and upon my never ceasing need of the aid of his Spirit to meet with temperance, fortitude and resignation the dispensations of his Providence yet awaiting me. After calling at the Marlborough Hotel and leaving my trunks, and at the Post-Office with my packets, I returned the Chaise at Spurr’s, and found Shaw at the Athenaeum. I went with him to W. Sullivan’s Office to speak of my proposal to have my son George’s name entered as a Law Student, on the books of the Suffolk Bar. But neither Sullivan, nor W. Spooner the Secretary of the Society were at their Offices. I went to Hilliard’s Book Store, and settled a Bill for George. Then to Mrs. Jenks’s where I met Degrand, with Lynde Walter, Mackay, and W. Taggard, a Committee of Merchants who delivered to me, a Memorial, to the President, urging the great necessity of a Bankrupt Law. They requested my aid also in obtaining the object of their petition to Congress— Degrand afterwards called again with Mr Davis the Editor of the Boston Patriot, and Dr Welsh came and passed an hour with me— Between 9 and 10 I left Mrs Jenks’s, called at the Athenaeum, wrote and left with Shaw an application to the Suffolk Bar, that my Son George may be allowed to Study two years under my own direction, and the third year with some member of the Bar within the Commonwealth— Degrand came with me to the Marlborough Hotel, and sat in conversation with me till between 11 and 12.

4. II:15. New-London. I left the Marlborough Hotel before three of the Morning, in a Stage, upon entering which, I found myself in the dark, with a multitude of fellow passengers among whom I had much ado, to stow myself away. As day dawned I discovered them to be twelve in number, men women and children, not one of whom was known to me— A Mr Hall, originally of Medford, but now of Baltimore, whither he was returning, with his wife and a small child, was of the company, and as we stopped at Dedham said that was the place where Coolidge declared he always took off his hat as he passed through because Fisher Ames was born there. At Walpole we breakfasted at Polley’s— I went over to Fuller’s and found that my wife and her party lodged there on Monday Night: and he told me that My Son George had written me a Letter Tuesday Morning which had been mailed at the next Post-Office— We reached Providence between ten and eleven, and changed Stages at Chapotin’s. There I met old Mrs Colman, mother of Mrs Chapotin who told me she had come there from her Son’s to attend the wedding of her Granddaughter. She is to be married next Tuesday to a Mr De Wolf; a son of the new Senator elect of the United States— My wife and family had lodged last Tuesday night at Chapotin’s— One of our Stage passengers left us at Providence, and in his stead we took up another, a Mr Newman— From Providence we travelled by a new Turnpike road, over an extraordinarily barren and desolate country 17 Miles to Greenwich, where we dined. Here we met the Stage from New-London, with the Steamboat Passengers— Among them was Mr. William King the Commissioner of Spanish Claims, returning from the second adjournment of the Commission— He told me there was great sickliness prevailing at Washington—but that Mr Crawford was convalescent and the Secretary of the Navy’s daughter Louisa had so far recovered that he had left Washington, with his family for New-York— After dinner we proceeded 18 Miles to Stonington; nearly the whole way within sight of the Sea— We stopped at Miner’s and found Mrs Adams had lodged there last Night. Thence we came 16 Miles, and crossing the Thames, alighted at Shepherd’s tavern in New-London, just at 9 in the Evening— Here I found my wife and family, as well as I could have expected, with the exception of the Coachman, who was ill in bed, with a violent fever, and to whom a physician, Dr. Perkins had been called— The house at Shepherd’s was crowded with company, a County Court being now in Session here— I was scarcely in the House when Mr. Henry Channing came to me, but it was merely to tell me that he would call on me again to-morrow Morning— This ride of ninety miles, after a nearly sleepless night, left me somewhat fatigued. The day has been remarkably fine.

5. VI:30. At breakfast this morning I met Mr Lanman the Senator of the United States, who was at New-London in attendance upon the Court. Mr Channing did not make his appearance; but Mr Green the Editor of the Newspaper, who had some years since, the printing of the Laws, and from whom it was at the application of the Connecticut delegation, transferred to another, came to solicit the restoration of it. He wished to obtain from me, a promise which I did not feel myself justified in giving— Some other persons were introduced to me, whose names escape my recollection— The Coachman was better this morning, but had still some fever— My wife, my Son George, and Mary Hellen, proceed with me in the Steam-Boats, for New-York, and we left Elizabeth, to nurse the Coachman, and come on, if he should be well enough, with the Carriage, by land, to-morrow. We left New London at 8 of the Morning, in the Steam-Boat Enterprize, Captn. Bunker junr. a temporary substitute for the regular Boat, the Fulton Captain Law, the machinery of which about ten days since became damaged, and is under repair. The Enterprize is a smaller Boat and belongs to New-York— We arrived at New-Haven about 3. in the afternoon— Most of my yesterday’s fellow-passengers came on with us, and many others from New-London; among them a very intelligent person, by the name of Howard, a resident of Savannah in Georgia— Mr Newman is a brother of the man who married Susan Buchanan, and remembered having been with Mrs Adams at the wedding. As the boat from New-York was not expected within two Hours, we walked into the town of New-Haven, and visited Hillhouse’s grave-yard, the principal curiosity of the place— Roger Sherman, and the Presidents of the College Stiles and Dwight are the principal tenants, in the tombs of this receptacle— There are a number of neat and some elegant marble monuments, but I think not one epitaph worth transcribing— We lingered however in this yard till 5 O’Clock, and on returning to the wharf came on board the Steam-Boat Connecticut, Captain Bunker senr. The Enterprize was at that moment casting off, and carried away several articles of our baggage which had been left in one of the births of the Lady’s cabin— We made an ineffectual attempt to recover them— I therefore wrote a Letter to Captain Bunker junr. which was forwarded by this Night’s mail, with a list of the missing articles, requesting him to give them to my Coachman if he should not have left New-London before receipt of the Letter, and otherwise, to forward them by the next Boat to New-York. We left the wharf in the Connecticut, about 6 in the Evening, with a very fresh breeze at S.S.W. approaching to a gale— It raised a heavy Sea, so that almost all the ladies were sick— The boat was crowded with passengers—nearly one hundred— Among the rest Mr Russ one of the members of the last Congress— Also a Mr and Mrs Delavan—the latter a woman of uncommon beauty.

6. V:30. Trenton. On rising this morning I found the Sands’s point light-house was a stern of our Boat, and by eight O’Clock we landed at New-York, and went to the City Hotel— My wife and son George were both much exhausted with fatigue— By our arrangements they are to remain at New-York till the Coachman and Elizabeth arrive there with our Carriage and Horses; but I was obliged to hasten onto reach Washington on the 10th. We Breakfasted with a Mrs Sturges of Savannah. I called at Mr M’Cormicks, and saw him and his young kinsman Mr Brodie. Mr M’Cormick told me that Mrs De Wint was in the City, lodging at a Mrs Powell’s, and Mr De Wint was to come down from Cedar Grove this Evening— I was going to call upon Mrs De Wint, when I met her with her daughter Carolina, her friend Mrs. Hook, and Charlton Clarkson, in Broadway, and returned with them to the City Hotel— I saw there also Captain Read of the Hornet and W. D. Lewis who told me he was going to Newport for some original Letters of L. Harris, which John D. Lewis has obtained at St. Petersburg, and sent to this Country, which will be used as evidence in the cause between Harris and W. D. Lewis. He also read me part of a Letter from his brother, mentioning
that the Commissioners named on the part of Harris for taking depositions had refused to act. I engaged my passage in the Stage and Steam-boat line for Philadelphia, and at 11. O’Clock crossed the North river in the ferry Boat to Powles Hoek, or the City of Jersey— Then immediately shipped in the Steam-boat Bellona, Captain Vanderbilt, and came to Brunswick— In this Boat I was again with an entire new set of fellow passengers, entire Strangers— We dined in the Boat, and reached Brunswick about 4 in the afternoon. At New-York, seeing advertised at a Booksellers shop window, the 3d. 4th. and 5th Cantos of Don Juan, just reprinted, there, I bought them, for a pastime on the way to Philadelphia; but I had read them through before we came to Brunswick. They are very licentious and very delightful— In the Ottava Rima of the Italians, like Boiardo, and Ariosto, and like Wieland’s Oberon in German. It is so desultory and digressive that he might spin it out into fifty or a hundred cantos if he pleased; but he intimates that it will be completed in twelve. There are descriptions, characters, bursts of tenderness, and flights of sublimity, mingled with sneers of religion and morals, unceasing sarcasms upon the female sex, and caustic Satire upon some of his living poetical rivals. At Brunswick we took the Stage, and came through Princeton 28 Miles to Trenton, which we reached about 9 in the Evening, and where stop for the Night.

7. V: We drove 3 Miles in the Stage to the landing, and there shipped in the Steam Boat Philadelphia Captain Jenkins, and arrived at Philadelphia just at ten O’Clock— I took a chamber at Miss Shinn’s South third Street N. 110. and immediately called upon S. Ewing, whom I found barely convalescent from a severe intermitting fever, which he took at his house in the Country, five or six miles from the City— He has three children afflicted with the same disease, and it is prevailing not only in the vicinity of Philadelphia, but throughout the interior of Pennsylvania— Commodore Murray died of it yesterday, and many whole families are confined with it. I returned to dinner at Miss Shinns’, and then went back to Ewing’s, and with his Sister, Mrs Hall, and her Son, to Church and heard Dr Wilson. His text was from Haggai 1.5. or 7. “Thus saith the Lord of Hosts; Consider your ways.” Dr Wilson is an able and eloquent presbyterian preacher, of the Calvinistic creed. He was formerly an eminent lawyer in the State of Delaware, and changed his profession in consequence of a tragical incident in his family. He preaches without notes, and his style is rather argumentative than rhetorical. Mr John Sergeant was there and I walked home with him. While I was with him Mr Benjamin Chew came in— Towards evening I called at Charles J. Ingersoll’s, and not finding him at home, at his brother Joseph R. Ingersoll’s, with whom I had some conversation concerning the cause of L. Harris against W. D. Lewis. I left with him J. R. Hurd’s Letter to me of September 1817. and requested him to have a supplementary deposition of Hurd taken to prove that he did write me that Letter. The trial is to come on in November. While I was with Ingersoll, his father came in; and afterwards his brother Charles, with whom I walked to his house. I had received from him a few days before I left Boston, a Letter, requesting me to call on him as I should pass through Philadelphia, for something concerning which he wished to speak to me; and to dine with him— But learning on my arrival here that his wife had been a few days since almost dying, and was yet confined to her bed with this raging disease, I had concluded he could with no convenience receive company to dinner, and had conditionally promised J. Sergeant to dine to-morrow with him— The point upon which Ingersoll had wished to speak to me was this— He asked me whether, at the Negotiation of the Treaty of Ghent, I had proposed to grant to the British the right of navigating the Mississippi River, as a compensation for an extension of our right to the fisheries. I said no— I had made no such proposition— But that the British Plenipotentiaries had notified to us
that they considered our rights of fishing within the British provincial jurisdiction, stipulated by an Article of the Treaty of Peace of 1783 as annulled by the War, and that they would not renew that Article. At the same time they demanded an Article in the proposed Treaty, securing to them the right of navigating the Mississippi— Our answer insisted that the Treaty of Peace of 1783 was not and could not be annulled by the War. That to pretend otherwise would be to say that our Independence was annulled by the War— But in that Treaty of 1783. there was a stipulation that the British should enjoy forever the right of navigating the Mississippi, and holding as we did that Treaty to be binding we declined agreeing to any new stipulation to that effect— In the course of the discussion we made a proposal to the British Plenipotentiaries, to adjust the difference by renewing both the Articles— To this Mr Clay objected, but he finally signed the Note which made the offer, Saying that he reserved to himself the right, if the whole Treaty should displease him finally to decline signing it— There was another proposal of the British, to renew an Article of Mr Jay’s Treaty giving access to the British traders from Canada, to the Indians within our Territories. To this . . . . Mr Clay declared that if it should be agreed to, and also the Article giving them the Navigation of the Mississippi, he would not sign the Treaty. . . . .would have signed the Treaty to include both the Articles Mr. Clay wished to give prodigious importance, to this British right of navigating the Mississippi, and fancied they would eagerly snatch at it, as an equivalent for the old fishing Article— But the truth was that they set so little value by it that they rejected our proposal without hesitation; and offered us a counter-proposal, to renounce the rights on both sides, which we in our turn rejected, and I then declared if it should be accepted that I would not sign the Treaty— Ingersoll said that it was intended to make use of this incident upon a future occasion against me. And that I shall be charged as specially the person who would have yielded to the British the right of navigating the Mississippi, for an extension of the fisheries— I said I had no doubt it would be used against me, wherever and whenever it could serve a turn. It had already been used against me in the Kentucky newspapers, and Mr. Clay in one of his speeches to the House of Representatives in Congress had made a statement of this incident, not in the most candid manner. For he had represented the proposal for allowing to the British the Navigation of the Mississippi, as having been made by a Majority, of the American Plenipotentiaries, he being in the minority, without acknowledging that he had signed the note by which the offer was made, and without disclosing how very lightly the concession of which he would fain make so much was estimated by the British, and how promptly they had rejected it— But in fact I was not the person who made the proposal for renewing the two Articles; it originated with Mr Gallatin, who knew and insisted that it could never be any thing to the British but a mere naked right, and of no more detriment to us than use to them— I told Ingersoll that I could shew him at Washington, in my private papers, all the documents exhibiting the true state of this affair, including the copy of the Note to the British Plenipotentiaries, containing the proposal, signed by Mr Clay, as well as by all the other American Commissioners— Ingersoll released me from the engagement to dine with him to-morrow, on account of his wife’s illness. I came back to my lodgings, about nine in the Evening.

8. VI:30. At breakfast this morning I recognized a Mr Nicholls, with whom I had an acquaintance almost intimate in 1802. 3. 4. and 5. but whom I do not recollect to have seen these fifteen years, and whom I had nearly forgotten— I remembered his person, though much altered, sometime before his name— I had visitors. J. Connell, who is to embark in the course of the week for France. Mr Garnett the member of Congress from Virginia with a Mr Corbin— And Mr John Vaughan, who invited me to spend this evening with him. I called at Joseph R. Ingersoll’s, and left Hurd’s Letter with him.
It was this day and not yesterday that his father came in while I was there. I called afterwards at J. Sergeant’s and told him, I would dine with him— While there the funeral of Commodore Murray went from the house of his next door neighbour Mr B. Chew— The procession was respectable but not very large. I went afterwards to Mr S. Ewing’s— He was himself better than yesterday but all the children had the fever upon them— Dr Chapman was with him— I returned and dined at J. Sergeant’s. Mrs. Sergeant was at table, though unwell with a severe cough— Sergeant’s brother Thomas, Genl. Cadwalader, and R. Walsh, formed the party, and Mr Reed came in after dinner— I spent the Evening at J. Vaughan’s with a company of 25 or 30 persons, among whom were Mr Patterson the director of the Mint, a Mr Robertson of South Carolina, and Mr Garnett— L. Harris was also there— Mr Vaughan accompanied me home to my lodgings.

9. VI:30. Early this morning, I walked round the city, and called at R. Walsh’s house, where I saw his wife and two children. He was already at his office. Called next at S. Ewing’s, and found him indisposed, having had a slight return of his fever— Then at the Athenaeum, where I met Mr Brown of Louisiana, and Mr Duponceau— Found Walsh at his office and had an hour’s conversation with him. He spoke of the state of public affairs in New-York, where the Convention is yet sitting at Albany, and where there is said to be as much canvassing for the next Presidential election, as repairing of Constitutions. He says that De Witt Clinton is politically speaking so completely broken down that he can never rise again. That in his private concerns he has a debt of 70000 dollars upon which from day to day he can scarcely keep the sheriff from his door; and that all his friends give up his case as absolutely desperate.— Walsh said also that Clinton had made last year a very foolish attack upon the National Administration, which he had utterly failed of supporting. But he added that New-York was of all the States in the Union, that most addicted to political bargaining and he thought the ultimate influence of the State would altogether depend upon caballing combinations. He hinted that it might very possibly be for Crawford— He said there were now occasionally breaking out in the Newspapers, in various parts of the Country, articles looking forward to the next Presidential election— Their general tenour was that it was too soon to open the discussion— But he was for breaking ground at no distant period; against the intriguing, bargaining, caucussing system, which is already in full operation— Walsh spoke likewise of the critiques which have appeared upon my fourth of July Address, and of his own comments upon it in the National Gazette of which he is the Editor; and he mentioned a series of numbers now in the course of publication, upon my Report on Weights and Measures. The reviewer was he said a Mr Plitt—a man well disposed, and familiar with the subject— From Walsh’s Office, I returned to Miss Shinns’, where I found a card of invitation from Mr Chew, to attend the late Commodore Murray’s funeral— But it was a day two late— General Cadwalader called upon me; and Connell, came and walked with me to the Steam-Boat Baltimore in which I embarked at Noon— There I met a very old acquaintance of mine a Mr Bayard, whom I had last seen on the 20th. of September 1801. at Providence— He was now in the Boat merely to take leave of a friend— A Mr Roy, of Virginia was introduced to me; going to Baltimore, and thence to Norfolk; whom I found so full of conversation, that I had no time for reading in the Bishop of Winchester’s life of William Pitt, which I bought at Maxwell’s shop in Philadelphia, for that purpose— We left the wharf at noon; reached Newcastle at 4. and proceeded, seven Stage-loads to Frenchtown. Just at 7. in the Evening we embarked in the Steam-Boat United States, Captain Trippe, with the Planet Venus just Setting in the West, and Jupiter with Saturn in conjunction rising in the East— One of the passengers whom I did not know, asked me to accept a small volume of poems lately published by a young man named
Percival, a Connecticut poet of 25— There were upwards of 70 passengers in the Steam-boat, many of them Ladies; and lots were drawn for the births— These boats go every day in the week, and the traveling has more than doubled since their invention— In the ease and comfort of travelling, the difference can scarcely be estimated.

10. Washington. The Steam-boat reached the wharf at Baltimore just as the Clock struck one, this morning. I did not quit my birth till about three, and then sat reading an hour before I left the boat— Between 4 and 5. I went up to Barnum’s tavern— Took my seat in the Stage of half-past five, and then went deliberately to bed— I was scarcely warm when the waiter called me up again— My Surtout had been among the articles left behind in the Steam-boat which returned from New-Haven to New-London; and I had purchased a Cloak yesterday at Philadelphia in anticipation of a cold Night— I found the benefit of it this Morning, and should have suffered without it— As I was stepping into the Stage, a Letter was handed to me, which I had not then time to read; but which I afterwards found was from Mr Lowrie, going out as consular agent to Laguayra and his object was to ask for a passage in a public ship— I had a new set of companions in the Stage; one of them a Scotch man named Jaffray, very talkative, and long settled in this country. We breakfasted at Merrill’s, the Waterloo tavern, 12 Miles from Baltimore, and just before Noon, I alighted at my own house, within the 24 hours from Philadelphia. Found the Servants whom we had left here, all well. I had met Major Roberdeau at Brown’s Hotel, who told me they were generally healthy at Georgetown; but in Washington it is sickly to an extraordinary degree; and many are perishing with the yellow fever at Alexandria— After taking possession of my writing room at home, I went to the Office of the Department of State, and there found the Clerks, all well, and despatches and Letters, more than the remnant of the day would suffice for reading— Among the rest, my Son George’s Letter from Walpole; and one from my wife at New-York, informing me that the Enterprize had returned, with all our missing Articles— At 5. I came home to dine, and found Johnson Hellen, who has remained here through the Summer. Mr Frye came and spent part of the Evening with me. I began reading the life of W. Pitt.

11. V: Resumed my customary mode of life, by rising an hour before the dawn, and lighting my candle and fire. Resumed also my Diary writing which has run into second arrears, from the 24th. of August. Dr Thornton called to see me at my house. At the Office there came Mr B. O. Tyler, Edward Wyer, who is but just recovering from a bilious fever, Mr William Taylor of Virginia, and Mr Calhoun who not long since returned home from the Bedford Springs. I found yet no time for writing at the Office— Mr Wirt the Attorney General, called at my house, but finding we were at dinner, left his name. I wrote to my wife, and addressed the Letter to Philadelphia—where I expect she will arrive to-morrow. I spent the Evening at Mr Calhoun’s where I met Mr Early, a brother of the late Governor of Georgia Peter Early.

12. VI:30. Rain, the whole day. Spent the morning in writing upon this diary at home, and wasted from Noon till 5 at the Office, reading despatches and Letters. Budgets received from J. B. Prevost, and from Jeremy Robinson in Chili. Letter from my Son George at New Brunswick— The Coachman and Elizabeth arrived at New-York, Monday Evening and Tuesday Mrs Adams came in the Steam-boat to New-Brunswick; leaving the carriage still to
follow her thither by land. I spent part of this Evening at my neighbour Dr Thornton’s, where I met Mr Walter Jones.— Reading the Life of Pitt.

13. VI:15. Morning calls from T. Cook, and J. Bailey. Visits from Governor Cass, of the Michigan territory, and General Macomb.— A young Frenchman by the name of Laborie, brought me two Letters from the Prince de Talleyrand; one, thanking me, for the copy which I sent him of my Report upon Weights and Measures; and the other a Letter of Recommendation, of Laborie himself. At the Office Edward Wyer called; and Mr Canning, the British Minister— He came to enquire, whether we could deliver up a certain Captain of a British fishing vessel, belonging to the Island of Newfoundland; who ran away with his vessel, and her fare of fish, and after disposing of part of his Cargo by smuggling on our Coast, entered one of our Eastern ports; and was there seized for a breach of our Revenue Laws— The crime of which this man is impeached is a Statute piracy, both by the British Laws, and our own. But our tribunals can take cognizance only of offences against our own Law, which can operate only upon offences within our jurisdiction; they cannot try this man, either upon our Statute, which he has not, or upon the British Statute which he has transgressed. I told Mr Canning that I thought we could not deliver up this man; and referred him to several cases of a similar character which have occurred before. He made some question as to the obligation by the Laws of Nations, to deliver up atrocious criminals—and referred to a passage in Vattel to that effect— I admitted that there was such a passage in Vattel; but said it was voluntary Law. In practice, Nations did as they pleased, some did, and some did not deliver up foreign criminals. England I believed did not— I mentioned to him the case of the pirates and murderers, on board the Schooner Plattsburg. Four of these were taken up in Denmark; one in Sweden; one in France and one in Prussia. We had demanded the delivery of them all; Denmark and Sweden had delivered; and we had tried, convicted, and executed the men— But France and Prussia, had refused to deliver; France alledging that she could deliver only after proof of the man’s guilt, which could be proved only by the trial, and Prussia, which took the trouble of sending the man from Dantzig to Elseneur, where ample testimony was produced against him, still refused to deliver him up because he did not confess his guilt— But with us the question was of the authority to deliver up— The Executive had no such authority; and if a warrant to take up the man should issue, the first judge upon whom he should call, would discharge him upon a Habeas-Corpus— [“]Ay, said Canning, this comes of a Republican Government.” Why, said I, we must take Republican Government like others, for better for worse: the personal security of individuals is a favourite object of Republican Government, but the want of authority was not confined to them. It had been the answer given by the Governor of Canada, to our application for the delivery of fugitive Slaves— Mr Canning had not been informed of this. I told him, if in this case he should make an application, I presumed the President would refer it to the Attorney General for a Report; but to save time I would send his papers to the Attorney General before transmitting them to the President— Mr Canning mentioned the case of a man named Milligan, charged with forging Bank Bills, in the State of New-York, who had been delivered up by the Government of Canada, but I was not acquainted with any of the particulars of the affair—nor was he. I walked this Evening with Johnson Hellen, down to Mr Frye’s, and spent an hour there.

14. VI: Heard Mr Little, at the Bath-room— He preached from 2. Corinthians 4.1.2. “Therefore seeing we have this ministry, as we have received mercy, we faint not;—But have renounced the hidden things of dishonesty, not walking in craftiness, nor handling the word of God deceitfully; but by manifestation of the truth commending ourselves to every man’s conscience in the sight of God.” It was a controversial Sermon about Unitarianism— One of the Georgetown College Jesuits named Kohbrann
has published a pamphlet purporting to be a complete refutation of the unitarian doctrine, to which Little has replied by a Sermon preached last Sunday, which is advertised for publication. That of this day was only supplementary to it— After Church I left a Card at Strother’s for Governor Cass; and then called on Dr Tucker at Mrs Wilson’s— I found lodging there two Mr Simmons’s, father and Son with their Ladies; they belong to South Carolina, and have been spending the Summer at Newport, Rhode-Island. The elder Mr Simmons told me, that they had been fellow passengers with me last Tuesday evening, in the Steam-boat from French-town to Baltimore. While I was there Major Van de Venter and Captain Smith, of the army came in— I went thence to Mr Crawford’s, and found him in his Bedchamber— Mr David Trimble the member of the House of Representatives from Kentucky was with him— Mr Crawford has been confined at least these six weeks with a severe bilious fever. His wife has also been dangerously ill, and his children and Servants have all shared in the epidemic. He told me that 17 persons have been affected by it in his family more or less— Many of them after apparent recovery have relapsed two, and some of them three times— They are now all convalescent, excepting his second son, Macon— He himself rides out, and is able to attend to business; but complains that he has not yet recovered his appetite, and said that yesterday for the first time, he found his usual symptom of health; a relish for a glass of cold water. Trimble is going to Boston— He is very lately from Kentucky; where, and in all the Western Country it has been as sickly as in this neighbourhood— Trimble said he had himself but just recovered from a severe bilious fever— On returning home I resumed my Diary and wrote till dinner time. Spent the Evening at Mr Wirt’s alone with him— Conversation chiefly upon the recent incidents in Florida— General Jackson, Judge Fromentin, and the late Spanish Governor, and Commissioner Callava— Jackson committed Callava to prison. Fromentin issued a writ of Habeas Corpus, with the intention of discharging Callava— Jackson summoned Fromentin before him to answer for having interfered with his authority— Fromentin first alledged sickness for not going; and afterwards went; not as he alledges, in obedience to the summons, but merely to give amicable explanations— There were violent scenes of altercations, between the parties; Callava has published a long protest against Jackson’s proceedings in the newspapers— Jackson and Fromentin have complained of each other to the Government, and all the newspapers are full of discussion upon the subject; generally taking side against Jackson, because they have seen hitherto little, but on one side of the questions— Among the rest the Richmond Enquirer a paper edited with considerable ability, and the organ of the new Virginia faction, under the auspices of Spenser Roane, chief Justice of that State has come out with great virulence— The Enquirer, under constant professions of esteem for Jackson’s public services has always betrayed a rancorous and malignant hostility against him. But Wirt has been himself heretofore a Correspondent of the Richmond Enquirer, and almost worships Spenser Roane— He is therefore alarmed at these premature ebullitions of the Press, and thinks there ought to be some anonymous counter publication in the National Intelligencer, to shield the Administration from censure. Wirt is inclined to think Jackson has been wrong, both in sending Callava to prison, and in summoning Fromentin before him— He thinks they were both priviledged persons— Callava, as the Spanish Commissioner, and Fromentin as a judge— I mentioned to him that Jackson had objected to the writ of Habeas Corpus, as issued illegally in form even if Fromentin had the right to issue it. Wirt said there could be no doubt that it was irregularly issued— Wirt thinks that the President should return to this City as soon as possible; to determine upon the course to be pursued in this case and some others after returning home, I read further in the life of W. Pitt.

15. VI. At the Office, the day was nearly occupied, by visits from Bresson one of the Secretaries of the French Legation, who brought me three Notes from the Baron Hyde de Neuville; from Baron
Stackelberg the Swedish Charge d’Affaires, and from Mr Calhoun. De Neuville’s Notes were to renew the demand for the restoration of the Jeune Eugénie, and to inform me, that he had received instructions from his Government, to continue the Negotiation concerning the 8th. Article of the Louisiana Treaty, and concerning the cases of the Apollon, Eugene and Neptune. Stackelberg came to claim privileges for Norwegian Vessels in our Ports, equal to those recently granted to our vessels in Norwegian Ports; which is not in the power of the Executive to allow— He also claimed like privileges for the vessels of the Island of St. Bartholomews. Stackelberg mentioned to me, the order of St Anne conferred by the Emperor of Russia upon his Minister here Mr Poletica, in reward for his services, manifested by the friendly relations existing between the two Governments. Stackelberg smiled significantly, on mentioning this, as if to hint that he knew Poletica had no friendship for this Government. I did not seem to understand him, but said I hoped that he too would some day receive a token of favour from his Sovereign, for the friendliness of the relations between our two Countries. He mentioned also Salmon’s case who he said had been Chargé d’Affaires from Spain, about half a day. General Vives, the former Spanish Minister having sailed from New-York on the 10th. of this Month; and Don Joaquin d’Anduaga, having arrived there on the morning of the 11th. Mr Calhoun came to mention the determination of the President, upon some question relating to the Barracks at St. Augustine— He also spoke of the altercations between Genl. Jackson, and Coll. Callava, and Judge Fromentin, about which he is much concerned. He thinks that the President ought to come immediately to the City, and determine upon the course to be pursued by the Administration, in these cases— I concur in that opinion— Calhoun fears that a wrong direction may be given to public sentiments, on these transactions by the Spirit of faction, and the crude precipitancy of newspaper Commentaries— Calhoun is a man of fair and candid mind; of honourable principles: of clear and quick understanding: of cool self-possession; of enlarged philosophical views, and of ardent patriotism— He is above all sectional, and factious prejudices, more than any other Statesman of this Union, with whom I have ever acted. He is more sensitive to the transient manifestations of momentary public opinion, more afraid of the first impressions of the public opinion than I am— In all cases of controvertible conduct in public men; when the conclusion upon the whole subject is more favourable than its first aspect, the more hastily and the more virulently they are in the first instance attacked, the more strong and effectual is the final recoil in their favour. In such cases I think the true policy is to let the hostile portion of the public Journals extravagate to their hearts content— Let them waste their strength, and emit all their venom, upon misapplications of Law, and perversions of fact; and when the victory is upon the balance, seize and turn their batteries against themselves— Mr Tobias Watkins the Secretary to the Commission upon Spanish Claims, called upon me this Evening, and had much conversation with me, concerning the proceedings of the Commissioners. He said he was confident the whole amount of the claims to be provided for would fall short of five Millions of Dollars, which would he thought be creditable to the Administration, which had been censured for not stipulating to pay a large sum, as Onis had demanded— I told him of the alarm which had been caused at Salem and Philadelphia, by the report that the Commissioners had decided not to admit any claim of Insurance Companies, or Underwriters. He said there had been no decision— The question had been reserved for argument. But two of the Commissioners, White and Tazewell had so strongly expressed their opinions, that he was fully convinced no underwriter or insurance company would recover a Cent. Mr King indeed was in their favour— But the opinion of the two others was very strong against them— I asked upon what grounds?— He said because the underwriters had received large premiums, often 50 per Cent, for the risks— Because the
Insurance Offices, had been more than compensated for their losses, by their profits; and Mr. Tazewell had another principle, namely that the Treaty provided for the claims only of American Citizens; and he did not know but some part of the Stock of Insurance Companies was owned by foreigners— Watkins said that Tazewell had written and discussed these and other questions arising from the Commission, in the form of dialogues— I told Watkins I hoped Mr White and Mr Tazewell would reconsider their opinions before they pronounced upon the claims of Insurance companies. I believed their claims good according to the maritime Law— The underwriter by payment of the loss acquired all the rights of salvage, belonging to the owner. We had renounced his claim upon the Spanish Government, and it would be hard to deprive him of all remedy, there with one hand and deny it to them with another here. The claims of the Insurance companies were among the principal claims to be provided for— We had published them to the world as claims of our Citizens of Spain; and now if they should be excluded, they would immediately come back against us as Claims upon Spain which we should again be obliged to maintain; and what could we say to Spain to maintain them?— Or what upon the subtle device that among fifty or a hundred american owners of Stock, in an Insurance company there might be one or two foreigners? They would charge us with direct fraud; and I think very justly— Watkins mooted the point with me some time, and I advised him to read Parke and Marshall and Louis the 14ths. Ordonnance de la Marine. He asked me, if I would commit to writing my ideas on the subject; but I declined, as it might have the appearance of interfering with the proceedings of the Commissioners— He said W. Pinkney was engaged to argue the question for the Insurance companies of Baltimore. I promised to refer to the cases of claims under the former Commissions both in France and England. He said the Commissioners had also decided that all the arguments should be in writing— But the counsel for one of the claimants had declared his wish to object to the admission of another claim; upon which Tazewell had said this was a new proposition, and it was further to be considered whether this argument should not be heard viva voce— After Watkins left me, I paid an evening visit to Madame de Neuville— Found Baron Stackelberg there; and all the French Legation— They removed the first of this month to Mrs Decatur’s house.

16. V:45. First day of the Washington City Races, and Dr Thornton’s horse Rattler, lost the race, to his great disappointment. I was not there— Mr Anderson the comptroller called on me. His wife and part of his family have been afflicted with the prevailing fever— Mr Joseph Nourse, the Register of the Treasury called at the Office, about an application which he made some time last Summer, for a namesake of his a Mr Henry Nourse, a British subject residing at the Cape of Good Hope and wishing for the appointment of American Consul there. I promised to remind the President of it. A young man by the name of Cooper, of Georgia, whose father lost a number of Slaves by capture from the British during the late war came to enquire into the State of the Negotiation upon the Subject. I told him that upon Mr Middleton’s arrival in Russia the Emperor had been absent, and very lately returned. We had as yet received no information that the subject of the arbitration had been brought before him; but I was assured Mr Middleton would not delay it. He asked upon what principle indemnity would be made if the decision should be in our favour— I said that indemnity for the mere value of the Slaves carried away, and only interest upon that value at the rate of six per Cent a year would be no adequate compensation for the loss. The increase of the Slave and the improvement of the
plantation by his labour ought to be paid for— I told him I thought it would be difficult to ascertain; he said not at all. I said it was like a merchant’s claiming for indemnity, the profits of a voyage which he might have made; but he did not see the analogy— I asked him how he could say that any given slave would not have died, within a week after he had been carried away— He said he could not; but allowance might be made for that— I advised that his father should have his whole argument set forth in its utmost extent and forwarded to this Department, where all the use that could, would be made of it— He took leave giving me thanks for my attendance to the business. I called at Mr Calhoun’s Office— Mr George Hay came to pay me a visit, and found us not risen from dinner— His little daughter Hortensia, has been very dangerously ill of the fever; and he is yet deeply concerned for her. I received a Letter from my wife at Philadelphia; from which I expect her here to-morrow. Received also a Letter from the President, and wrote one to him, suggesting his return as soon as convenient to this city. He writes that he will come if desired.

17. VI:Mr Calhoun called upon me this morning at my house and we had a long conversation upon political affairs at home and abroad. I shewed him the Letters I have last received from C. Hughes junr. and H. Middleton. Mr Canning came to the Office, again upon the Affair of the Pirates from Newfoundland— He had written me a note upon the Subject, which I first shewed to the Attorney General, and then sent to the President— I spoke of it last Sunday to Mr Wirt, who said he had already given an opinion in a similar case, a copy of which he supposed would suffice if the President should refer this to him. Mr Canning discussed again the question of the obligation of Nations to deliver up atrocious criminals, and alluded to the British Acts of Parliament which authorize the Government to send foreigners out of the Kingdom; which I observed to him was quite a different thing from delivering them up, at the demand of another power. Mr Canning had read the Statute of the United States for punishing crimes, and thought its provisions against piracy, sufficiently comprehensive to include this case— And in words it certainly is; but I referred him to the construction which the Supreme Court of the United States have given to that Section of the Statute, in Palmer’s case, which restricts its operation to our own Citizens, or offences in our own vessels. And I read to him in the third Volume of Wheaton’s Reports a part of the opinion of the Court in that case— On returning home to dinner I found that Elizabeth, the Chambermaid had got home— She came in the Stage from Baltimore— And about eight in the Evening, my wife, with my Son George and Mary Hellen arrived in the Carriage; all as well, as I could have reason to hope— Coachman not entirely recovered— Dr Thornton won this day’s race.

18. VI: My Son George this day commenced upon the study of the Law, under my own direction. He is to follow his reading, in my own writing-room, and I gave him Hallam’s History of the Middle ages to begin with— A Mr Burdick came to my house upon the subject of a Patent— I referred him to Dr Thornton. Governor Cass of the Michigan Territory came to the Office with a Mr Hunt, lately from Detroit. I received a Letter from R. Purdy, Marshal of West Tennessee, against whom there have been complaints by one of his Assistants in taking the Census— Judge Overton, and both the Senators from Tennessee have written to me, testifying to the good character of the Marshal, who has also written me a Letter very indignant against the complaining assistant. It happens unfortunately that upon the merits of this particular case, the Marshal is wrong. We had visitors this Evening; the Baron Hyde de Neuville, the French Minister, with young Laborie, and also Mr Bailey. The sickliness still continues here, and the yellow fever at Alexandria. The first frost was on
the morning that I came home— A white frost which we remarked as we came out of Baltimore. There have also been frosts the last two or three Nights. They will probably stay the progress of the Epidemic, but prove fatal to some who are already affected with it— Richard C. Norton died of the yellow fever on the thirteenth, and Mr Samuel Elliot, of bilious fever, yesterday in the neighbourhood of this City.— Johnson Hellen received this morning an invitation to attend this Evening the wedding of Mr T. Cook, but did not go. Cook was married to a widow Catherine Wilson, of Philadelphia.

19. VI.Mr Hill, who acted some time as our commercial agent at Valparaiso in Chile, called at my house this morning— He returned to this Country last Summer in the Macedonian frigate. Comes here only to pass one or two days— He came in the Steamboat with Mrs Adams from Philadelphia to Baltimore. Judge Cranch called at my house, and mentioned some particulars of the illness and death of R. C. Norton, his nephew and Son in Law, and of S. Eliothis wife’s nephew. Norton’s was yellow fever— Eliot had all the symptoms of it, excepting the black vomit— Mr Daniel Brent came to call upon Mrs Adams. I went at one O’Clock with George and Johnson Hellen to Mr Moulder’s, to a collation upon the occasion of T. Cook’s marriage— Moulder is Cook’s next door neighbour, and the bride, is his wife’s sister— We met there a room full of gentlemen, and I dined on the collation. Mr. Calhoun called at my Office, and we had further Conversation concerning the late transactions in Florida. I wrote a Letter to the President to be sent to-morrow, but received a message from his house, that he would himself return to-morrow to the City— As I was returning home from my Office, I met Coll. Bomford, who walked with me, and related many particulars of the prevailing epidemic, which has been very severe, and in many cases fatal— Mr and Mrs Frye came and spent the Evening with us.

20. V:30— Walk with George over the Tyber by the Bridge near the old Theatre; and returned by the new Bridge from 14th. Street, which has been built this Season, and opened while I was absent— There were received this morning from the President a number of bundles of papers, forwarded by him from Oakhill; some of them public papers to be deposited at the Department; others which he had directed to be sent to his house— Among them was a Letter from Spencer Roane, the Virginian-Chief-Justice, enclosing to him his lucubrations in the Richmond Enquirer, against the Supreme Court of the United States— George Hay told me last Summer that Roane was the author of the pieces signed Algernon Sidney, against the Supreme Court, and that they had been excited by the words “we command you” in the Mandamus, in the case of Cohens vs Virginia— Roane in his Letter to the President glorifies himself as a very virtuous patriot, and holds himself out as a sort of Jefferson or Madison— All this is “close ambition varnished o’er with zeal.” Jefferson and Madison did attain power by organizing and heading a system of attack upon the Washington Administration, chiefly under the banners of State rights and State Sovereignty— They argued and scolded against all implied powers, and pretended that the Government of the Union had no powers but such as were expressly delegated by the Constitution— They succeeded. Mr Jefferson was elected President of the United States, and the first thing he did was to purchase Louisiana. An assumption of implied power, greater in itself and more comprehensive in its consequences, than all the assumptions of implied powers, in the twelve years of the Washington and Adams administrations put together. Through the sixteen years of the Jefferson and Madison Administrations not the least regard was paid to the doctrines of rejecting implied powers, upon which those Gentlemen had vaulted into the seat of Government, with the single exception that Mr Madison negatived a Bill for applying public money to the public internal improvement of the Country. But the same Mr Madison signed a Bill for incorporating a Bank of the United States, against which he and all the Virginian party had stubbornly contended as Unconstitutional, because express power was not given to the Congress to incorporate Banks— The Virginian opposition to implied powers therefore is a convenient weapon, to be taken up or laid aside as it suits the purposes of State turbulence and ambition; and as Virginia has no direct Candidate to offer for the next Presidential Election, her aspiring
demagogues, are casting about them to place her again at the head of a formal opposition to the administration of the Union; that she may thus again obtain by conquest the administration itself. On the former occasion this attempt was greatly favoured by circumstances— It was favoured by its novelty— Favoured by the bad management of its adversaries. It has most of the same advantages now— They still possess in a superior degree the art of political management— They will be favoured by circumstances; and if not by novelty, yet by the success of the former example— The tactics of the former war are again resorted to, and Roane comes forth as the champion of Virginia— There was also among the papers a copy of the President’s answer to this Letter; declining a positive answer upon the special point of Roane’s assault; but giving countenance to it, by referring to his own resistance against the right of the general Government to make internal improvements— I called about seven this Evening at the President’s House to enquire if he had returned home. He had not arrived, and Mr Hay, after waiting for him till that time, had just sat down to dinner— I came home and read in Pitt’s life, and one Act of Ben Johnson’s Every man in his humour— George read, Hallam in the morning and Cicero afternoon.

21. V:45. Heard, with George, Mr Little, who preached from 1. John 3.2.3. “Beloved, now are we the sons of God, and it doth not yet appear what we shall be; but we know that, when he shall appear, we shall be like him; for we shall see him as he is— And every man that hath this hope in him purifieth himself, even as he is pure.” The discourse was upon the probable condition of our existence in a future world— Ingenious; but conjectural, and certainly not well founded— For that condition of existence, who by searching can find it out? Let us adore and wait in humble resignation— Returning home we met Mr George Hay at Mr Calhoun’s door— He told us the President had not yet returned to the City; and advised us not to walk in the Sun without an Umbrella— It is considered here as hazarding a fever even so late in the Season as this— I called and paid a visit to my neighbour Mr Joseph Wheaton and Mr James Greenleaf who lodges at his house. Received visits from Dr Tucker and Mr William Lee. Read in Pitt’s Life, in the Evening.

22. V: The Messenger of the Department of State, who calls every Monday Morning at my house, to take the Letters of the Sunday’s Mail to the Office; told me this morning that the President had returned last Evening to the City— I called at his house, and Mr Calhoun came in while I was there. I had some desultory conversation with him concerning the case of the French vessel La Jeune Eugénie, and Lieutt. Stockton, and also concerning Jackson’s transactions with Callava and Fromentin— These are all subjects of very insignificant import in themselves; but very important, from circumstances and principles connected with them— The President is not a little embarrassed with them both. I have received a Letter from him upon the affair of Callava, almost unintelligible— He directed a meeting of the members of the Administration at his house to-morrow at Noon— I had received last week a Letter from Don Joaquin d’Anduaga, at Philadelphia, announcing his arrival there; and requesting to be informed when he could have an Audience of the President to deliver his credential letter— I answered him this day; that the President having now returned to the City would readily grant him an audience, to receive his credential; and that I shall be happy to see him at the Department, at any time that would suit his convenience— Wrote also to Litell and Henry Booksellers at Philadelphia, to subscribe for a projected Edition of Blackstone’s Commentaries— In the Evening read an act of Every Man in his humour, and in Pitt’s Life.

23. V: There was a meeting of the members of the Administration at the President’s at Noon— Mr Calhoun and Mr Wirt present— The transactions in Florida, were the subject of deliberation.
There was first a military question. The new organization of the army began on the first of June last— From that time General Jackson’s command ceased— He has continued to issue orders to the troops in the same manner, as while he was in the military service— They have been obeyed; but Coll. Brooke, the Officer in command at Pensacola, has written to enquire of General Brown, whether he is subject to the military command of General Jackson, and safe, in obeying his orders— Brown answers not only in the negative; but expresses surprize that such a question should ever have been made— Brown’s Letter however passed through the War Department, and has not yet been transmitted to Brook— The question was now discussed. The President and Mr Wirt, thought Jackson had no command— Calhoun inclined to the same opinion, but said he knew that Jackson had acted upon full deliberation and advisement. I thought he had decided correctly—his Commission having given him the powers not only of Governor, but of the Captain General of Cuba, which was of course, the Military command in chief throughout the Province— I observed that the military was the only executive power in the Province—and that if the Governor had no military command, he had no effective authority; no means of executing his decrees; administrative or Judicial. Mr. Wirt said he might employ the Militia. But there was no Militia in Florida— Wirt said Jackson had organized Counties and introduced Juries— Could he not by the same authority have constituted a Militia?— perhaps he might— But how were they to be armed; officered; trained; disciplined? at what enormous expence must they be made effective; and all for a mere interval between the taking of possession of the Province, and the next Session of Congress—and all to perform a service which could be executed by a file of fifty soldiers, who have nothing else to do. The President, mentioned that this question had occurred last Spring, and he had conversed with General Gaines concerning it; Gaines had at first been named as the Officer to take possession of East-Florida— But it had not then been thought necessary to decide the question— Gaines had told him he would take care that no collision should arise upon it between Jackson and him— I asked, what necessity, there was for deciding it now. It was after all a mere question of form— If Jackson could not as Governor issue direct orders, as a Military commander, he could issue requisitions to the very same effect; and which the troops were just as much bound to obey. Calhoun said they were now actually obeyed; and would be so till counter-orders should be received from hence. The question might therefore be left undecided— It was therefore postponed— The next point considered was the controversy between General Jackson and Judge Fromentin— The opinion was unanimous that as the only Laws extended to the territory, were those of the revenue and against the Slave-trade; Fromentin’s jurisdiction was confined to them; and he had no right to issue the writ of Habeas Corpus, to liberate Callava. But the President, Mr Calhoun and Mr Wirt were of opinion that Fromentin having issued the writ though erroneously in his judicial capacity was not amenable for it to Jackson, and that Jackson had no right to summon him before him to answer for it. I thought he had. For it being admitted that Fromentin had no right to issue the writ of Habeas Corpus, the act was an act of most dangerous resistance against Jackson’s lawful authority, for which it appears to me he was authorised to summon Fromentin before him to answer for the contempt— I read the Letter from judge Fromentin to me, of 6. September, and its enclosures—the language used in it is very intemperate, and full of exasperation— At 4 O’Clock the discussion was not near being exhausted, and the meeting was adjourned till to-morrow Noon. The President had anonymous letter, warning him that there was a pamphlet against him about being published— He tore it up and burnt it saying that he received many such letters. Mr Watkins, the
Secretary to the Commission upon Spanish claims paid us an Evening visit. George and Johnson Hellen dined with Mr T. Cook; and in the Evening, I read Lord Byron’s English bards and Scotch Reviewers.

24. V:15.Mr Seaton the junior Editor of the National Intelligencer, came to the Office, to request an advance upon the printing of the Census, to which I agreed— Adjourned Cabinet Meeting at the President’s— I received and took with me, a Letter from Governor Jackson, enclosing a proclamation, ordering several Spanish Officers who had remained there, to depart from the Province within four days. They had published in the Newspapers, a Declaration highly insulting to him, upon the affair of Callava— I told the President that upon further reflection I thought if he had made up his mind that General Jackson had no right to issue military orders to our troops stationed in the Province, both General Jackson and Coll Brook ought to be informed of it; because cases might arise in which the legality or illegality of his orders might be of infinite importance— It appeared that in Callava’s case, there had been threats on his part of resistance by force and of bloodshed—and that Coll. Butler’s soldiers had primed and loaded their muskets in front of Callava’s house. Violence might in the state of things there be expected; and if it should occur upon illegal orders, issued after the Government have had time and opportunity to forbid them blame would fall upon the Administration for the omission to give notice to the parties implicated, of the President’s determination— The question as to the right was then discussed again— Mr Wirt argued the point as he naturally and properly does all questions in the Cabinet, as a lawyer— He seemed to think, that General Jackson’s powers, being those heretofore exercised by the Provincial Governors, and by the Governor and Captain General of Cuba, could have operation, only upon the old inhabitants, and not upon Citizens of the United States. And he remarked that the object for which those powers were conferred upon Jackson was to maintain the old Spanish Inhabitants in the enjoyment of their Liberty, property and religion; provisionally and until they can be admitted to all the rights and privileges of Citizens of the United States— This was the stipulation of the Treaty; made for the benefit of the Spanish inhabitants— How then could Jackson exercise authority over Citizens of the United States? How could he have any command of the army; the creature of the Law; governed by the Articles of War, and having only the Officers and Commanders recognized by Law? All this appeared to me to be very sound reasoning; taking departure from the Constitution and Laws of the United States; with all our principles restrictive of power; and our cardinal maxim of separating the civil from the Military authority, and the Legislative, Executive and Judicial powers from each other— But nothing of all this is suited to the occasion— We have acquired a Spanish Province, heretofore governed by arbitrary principles and by military rule— Congress had not time at their last Session to introduce our checked and balanced system of Government there— They continued therefore until their next Session the antient system of Government; and all the powers formerly exercised by the Supreme Rulers of the Province were vested in the Governor. The military was their only executive— To deny the Governor the right to command the Soldiers, was to strip him of all effective power— If Citizens of the United States went into the Province, they must go and abide there conformably to the Law of the time and the place— They cannot carry the Constitution or the Laws of the United States there with them— To this, the authority of Congress is alone competent. The question whether Jackson can command, the troops is a question merely of forms. And where there is nothing but form at issue, I cannot perceive the use of attaching much importance to it— The more direct the power to command is, the more effective it will be to its purpose; nor do I perceive any inconvenience in direct command, more than would be incident to subsidiary
requisition— Mr Calhoun expressed a doubt whether Jackson had the power to order the Spanish Officers out of the Province— Neither he nor Wirt seemed capable of realizing the exercise of absolute power by an American Governor— Calhoun said he was afraid the Officers would not go; in which case Jackson would certainly send them to Jail; in short he lived he said in continual fear of hearing from mail to mail of some Tragedy happening there.
